<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Heroin skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Heroin</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Distinguish&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Distinguish (page does not exist)">Template:Distinguish</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_dmy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use dmy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use dmy dates</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi-indef</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Drugbox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Drugbox (page does not exist)">Template:Drugbox</a>
<b>Heroin</b> (<b>diacetylmorphine</b> or <b>morphine diacetate</b> (<a href="/wiki/International_Nonproprietary_Name" title="International Nonproprietary Name">INN</a>)), also known as <b>diamorphine</b> (<a href="/wiki/British_Approved_Name" title="British Approved Name">BAN</a>), and colloquially as <b>H</b>, <b>smack</b>, <b>horse</b>, <b>brown</b>, <b>black</b>, <b>tar</b>, and other names,<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> is an <a href="/wiki/Opioid" title="Opioid">opioid</a> <a href="/wiki/Analgesic" title="Analgesic">analgesic</a> synthesized by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charles_Romley_Alder_Wright&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charles Romley Alder Wright (page does not exist)">C.R. Alder Wright</a> in 1874 by adding two acetyl groups to the molecule <a href="/wiki/Morphine" title="Morphine">morphine</a>, found in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Opium_poppy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Opium poppy (page does not exist)">opium poppy</a>. It is the 3,6-<a href="/wiki/Acetate" title="Acetate">diacetyl</a> <a href="/wiki/Ester" title="Ester">ester</a> of morphine. Heroin itself is an active drug, but it is also converted into morphine in the body.<sup id="cite_ref-Sawynok_1986_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sawynok_1986-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>When used in medicine, it is typically used to treat severe pain, such as that resulting from a heart attack or a severe injury. The name "heroin" is usually only used when being discussed in its illegal form. When it is used in a medical environment, it is referred to as diamorphine. The white crystalline form considered "pure heroin" is usually the <a href="/wiki/Hydrochloride" title="Hydrochloride">hydrochloride</a> salt, diacetylmorphine hydrochloride. Bayer named the first diamorphine product Heroin; that brand name is now used primarily to describe illicit diacetylmorphine.
</p><p>Illicit heroin is sometimes available in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Free_base&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Free base (page does not exist)">freebase</a> form, dulling the sheen and consistency to a matte-white powder.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> Because of its lower <a href="/wiki/Boiling_point" title="Boiling point">boiling point</a>, the freebase form of heroin is also smokable. It is prevalent in heroin coming from <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, which as of 2004 produced roughly 87% of the world supply in illicit <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raw_opium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raw opium (page does not exist)">raw opium</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-UNODCSurvey_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNODCSurvey-4">[4]</a></sup> However, the production rate in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mexico (page does not exist)">Mexico</a> has risen sixfold from 2007 to 2011, changing that percentage and placing Mexico as the second largest opium producer in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexican cartels are also known to produce a third type of illicit heroin, commonly called <a href="/wiki/Black_tar_heroin" title="Black tar heroin">black tar</a>, which results from a simplified, quicker <a href="/wiki/Chemical_synthesis" title="Chemical synthesis">synthesis</a> procedure and contains a high percentage of morphine derivates other than heroin, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=6-Monoacetylmorphine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="6-Monoacetylmorphine (page does not exist)">6-Monoacetylmorphine</a> (6-MAM).
</p><p>As with other <a href="/wiki/Opioids" title="Opioids" class="mw-redirect">opioids</a>, diacetylmorphine is used as both an <a href="/wiki/Analgesic" title="Analgesic">analgesic</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Recreational_drug" title="Recreational drug" class="mw-redirect">recreational drug</a>. Frequent and regular administration is associated with <a href="/wiki/Drug_tolerance" title="Drug tolerance">tolerance</a> and <a href="/wiki/Physical_dependence" title="Physical dependence">physical dependence</a>. Internationally, diacetylmorphine is controlled under Schedules I and IV of the <a href="/wiki/Single_Convention_on_Narcotic_Drugs" title="Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs">Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> It is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Drug_prohibition_law&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Drug prohibition law (page does not exist)">illegal</a> to manufacture, possess, or sell diacetylmorphine without a <a href="/wiki/License" title="License">license</a> in almost every country.
</p><p>Under the chemical names diamorphine and diacetylmorphine, heroin is a legally <a href="/wiki/Prescription_drug" title="Prescription drug">prescribed</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Controlled_drug&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Controlled drug (page does not exist)">controlled drug</a> in the United Kingdom, and is supplied in tablet or injectable form for the same indications as <a href="/wiki/Morphine#Medical_uses" title="Morphine">morphine</a> is, often being preferred over morphine due to its lower side-effect profile.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} It is also available for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Heroin_maintenance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Heroin maintenance (page does not exist)">prescription to long-term users</a> as a form of <a href="/wiki/Opioid_replacement_therapy" title="Opioid replacement therapy">opioid replacement therapy</a> in the Netherlands, United Kingdom, Switzerland, Germany, and Denmark, alongside <a href="/wiki/Counseling" title="Counseling" class="mw-redirect">psycho-social care</a>—in the same manner that <a href="/wiki/Methadone" title="Methadone">methadone</a> or <a href="/wiki/Buprenorphine" title="Buprenorphine">Suboxone (buprenorphine)</a> are used in the United States and Canada<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>—and a similar programme is being campaigned for by liberal political parties in Norway.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Usage">Usage</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Long-term_effects_of_heroin.png" title="File:Long-term effects of heroin.png">File:Long-term effects of heroin.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Long-term effects of intravenous usage, including – and indeed primarily because of – the effects of the contaminants common in illegal heroin and contaminated needles.<sup id="cite_ref-ONDCP_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ONDCP-9">[9]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Short-term_effects_of_heroin.png" title="File:Short-term effects of heroin.png">File:Short-term effects of heroin.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Short-term effects of usage<sup id="cite_ref-ONDCP_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ONDCP-9">[9]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The BBC reported that "Worldwide, the UN estimates that as of 2005, there are more than 50 million regular users of heroin, cocaine and synthetic drugs."<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> Global users of diacetylmorphine are estimated at between 15 and 21 million people aged 15–64.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Medical_use">Medical use</span></h3>
<p>Under the chemical name diamorphine, diacetylmorphine is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prescription_medicine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prescription medicine (page does not exist)">prescribed</a> as a strong <a href="/wiki/Analgesic" title="Analgesic">analgesic</a> in the United Kingdom, where it is given via <a href="/wiki/Subcutaneous" title="Subcutaneous" class="mw-redirect">subcutaneous</a>, <a href="/wiki/Intramuscular" title="Intramuscular" class="mw-redirect">intramuscular</a>, <a href="/wiki/Intrathecal" title="Intrathecal">intrathecal</a> or <a href="/wiki/Intravenous" title="Intravenous" class="mw-redirect">intravenous</a> route. Its use includes treatment for acute pain, such as in severe <a href="/w/index.php?title=Physical_trauma&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Physical trauma (page does not exist)">physical trauma</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Myocardial_infarction&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Myocardial infarction (page does not exist)">myocardial infarction</a>, post-surgical pain, and chronic pain, including end-stage cancer and other <a href="/wiki/Terminal_illness" title="Terminal illness">terminal illnesses</a>. In other countries it is more common to use <a href="/wiki/Morphine" title="Morphine">morphine</a> or other strong <a href="/wiki/Opioids" title="Opioids" class="mw-redirect">opioids</a> in these situations. In 2004, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Institute_for_Health_and_Clinical_Excellence&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (page does not exist)">National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence</a> (a non-departmental public body of the Department of Health in the United Kingdom) produced guidance on the management of <a href="/wiki/Caesarian_section" title="Caesarian section" class="mw-redirect">caesarian section</a>, which recommended the use of intrathecal or epidural diacetylmorphine for post-operative pain relief.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2005, there was a shortage of diacetylmorphine in the UK, because of a problem at the main UK manufacturers.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Because of this, many hospitals changed to using <a href="/wiki/Morphine" title="Morphine">morphine</a> instead of diacetylmorphine. Although there is no longer a problem with the manufacturing of diacetylmorphine in the UK, some hospitals there have continued to use morphine. The majority, however, continue to use diacetylmorphine, and diacetylmorphine tablets are supplied for <a href="/wiki/Pain_management" title="Pain management">pain management</a>.
</p><p>Diacetylmorphine continues to be widely used in <a href="/wiki/Palliative_care" title="Palliative care">palliative care</a> in the United Kingdom, where it is commonly given by the <a href="/wiki/Subcutaneous" title="Subcutaneous" class="mw-redirect">subcutaneous</a> route, often via a <a href="/wiki/Syringe_driver" title="Syringe driver">syringe driver</a>, if patients cannot easily swallow <a href="/wiki/Morphine" title="Morphine">oral morphine solution</a>. The advantage of diacetylmorphine over <a href="/wiki/Morphine" title="Morphine">morphine</a> is that diacetylmorphine is more <a href="/wiki/Lipophilicity" title="Lipophilicity">fat soluble</a> and therefore more potent (by injection only), so smaller doses of it are needed for the same analgesic effect. Both of these factors are advantageous if giving high doses of opioids via the <a href="/wiki/Subcutaneous" title="Subcutaneous" class="mw-redirect">subcutaneous</a> route, which is often necessary in <a href="/wiki/Palliative_care" title="Palliative care">palliative care</a>.
</p><p>The medical use of diacetylmorphine (in common with other strong <a href="/wiki/Opioids" title="Opioids" class="mw-redirect">opioids</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Morphine" title="Morphine">morphine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fentanyl" title="Fentanyl">fentanyl</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oxycodone" title="Oxycodone">oxycodone</a>) is controlled in the United Kingdom by the <a href="/wiki/Misuse_of_Drugs_Act_1971" title="Misuse of Drugs Act 1971">Misuse of Drugs Act 1971</a>. In the UK, it is a class A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Controlled_drug&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Controlled drug (page does not exist)">controlled drug</a> and as such is subject to guidelines surrounding its storage, administration and destruction. Possession of Diamorphine without a prescription is an arrestable offence. When Diamorphine is prescribed in a hospital or similar environment, its administration must be supervised by 2 people who must then complete and sign a CD register detailing the patients name, amount, time, date and route of administration. In the case of a doctor administering diamorphine, then he/she may administer the drug alone, however the rule requiring two registered practitioners (e.g. a nurse, midwife or another doctor) to sign the CD register still applies. The use of a "witness" when administering Diamorphine is to avoid the possibility of the drug being diverted onto the black market.
</p><p>For safety reasons, many UK <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Health_Service&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Health Service (page does not exist)">National Health Service</a> hospitals now only permit the administration of intravenous diamorphine in designated areas. In practice this usually means a <a href="/wiki/Critical_care_unit" title="Critical care unit" class="mw-redirect">critical care unit</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Accident_and_emergency" title="Accident and emergency" class="mw-redirect">accident and emergency</a> department, operating theatres by an <a href="/wiki/Anaesthetist" title="Anaesthetist" class="mw-redirect">anaesthetist</a> or <a href="/wiki/Nurse_anesthetist" title="Nurse anesthetist">nurse anaesthetist</a> or other such areas where close monitoring and support from senior staff is immediately available. However, administration by other routes is permitted in other areas of the hospital. This includes subcutaneous, intramuscular, intravenously as part of a <a href="/wiki/Patient_controlled_analgesia" title="Patient controlled analgesia" class="mw-redirect">patient controlled analgesia</a> setup, and as an already established <a href="/wiki/Epidural" title="Epidural">epidural</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Infusion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Infusion (page does not exist)">infusion pump</a>. Subcutaneous infusion, along with subcutaneous and intramuscular 'bolus' administration is often used in the patient's own home, in order to treat severe pain in terminal illness.
</p><p>Diacetylmorphine is also used as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Heroin_maintenance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Heroin maintenance (page does not exist)">maintenance drug</a> to treat certain groups of addicts, normally long term chronic IV heroin users, and even in these situations it is only prescribed following exhaustive efforts at treatment via other means. It is thought that heroin users can walk into a clinic and walk out with a prescription but the process takes many weeks before a prescription for Diacetylmorphine is issued. Though this is somewhat controversial among proponents of a <a href="/wiki/Zero_tolerance" title="Zero tolerance">zero tolerance</a> drug policy, it has proven superior to <a href="/wiki/Methadone" title="Methadone">methadone</a> in improving the social and health situation of addicts.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> See: <a href="#Prescription_for_addicts">Heroin prescription for addicts</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Recreational_use">Recreational use</span></h3>
<p>Diacetylmorphine, almost always still called by its original trade name of heroin in non-medical settings, is used as a recreational drug for the <a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/transcendent" class="extiw" title="wiktionary:transcendent">transcendent</a> relaxation and intense <a href="/w/index.php?title=Euphoria_(emotion)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Euphoria (emotion) (page does not exist)">euphoria</a> it induces. <a href="/wiki/Anthropology" title="Anthropology">Anthropologist</a> Michael Agar once described heroin as "the perfect whatever drug."<sup id="cite_ref-agar_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agar-15">[15]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Physiological_tolerance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Physiological tolerance (page does not exist)">Tolerance</a> develops quickly, and users need more of the drug to achieve the same effects. Its popularity with recreational drug users, compared to <a href="/wiki/Morphine" title="Morphine">morphine</a>, reportedly stems from its perceived different effects.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> In particular, users report an intense <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rush_(psychology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rush (psychology) (page does not exist)">rush</a>, an acute transcendent state of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Euphoria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Euphoria (page does not exist)">euphoria</a>, which occurs while diacetylmorphine is being metabolized into 6-monoacetylmorphine (6-MAM) and morphine in the brain. Some believe that heroin produces more euphoria than other opioids upon injection; one possible explanation is the presence of 6-monoacetylmorphine, a metabolite unique to heroin – although a more likely explanation is the rapidity of onset. While other opioids of recreational use produce only morphine, heroin also leaves 6-MAM, also a psycho-<a href="/w/index.php?title=Active_metabolite&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Active metabolite (page does not exist)">active metabolite</a>. However, this perception is not supported by the results of clinical studies comparing the physiological and subjective effects of injected heroin and morphine in individuals formerly addicted to opioids; these subjects showed no preference for one drug over the other. Equipotent injected doses had comparable action courses, with no difference in subjects' self-rated feelings of euphoria, ambition, nervousness, relaxation, drowsiness, or sleepiness.<sup id="cite_ref-martin_and_fraser_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-martin_and_fraser-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p><p>Short-term addiction studies by the same researchers demonstrated that tolerance developed at a similar rate to both heroin and morphine. When compared to the opioids <a href="/wiki/Hydromorphone" title="Hydromorphone">hydromorphone</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fentanyl" title="Fentanyl">fentanyl</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oxycodone" title="Oxycodone">oxycodone</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pethidine" title="Pethidine">pethidine</a>/<a href="/wiki/Meperidine" title="Meperidine" class="mw-redirect">meperidine</a>, former addicts showed a strong preference for heroin and morphine, suggesting that heroin and morphine are particularly susceptible to abuse and addiction. Morphine and heroin were also much more likely to produce euphoria and other positive subjective effects when compared to these other opioids.<sup id="cite_ref-martin_and_fraser_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-martin_and_fraser-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some researchers have attempted to explain heroin use and the culture that surrounds it through the use of sociological theories. In <i>Righteous Dopefiend</i>, Philippe Bourgois and Jeff Schonberg use <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anomie_theory&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anomie theory (page does not exist)">anomie theory</a> to explain why people begin using heroin. By analyzing a community in San Francisco, they demonstrated that heroin use was caused in part by internal and external factors such as violent homes and parental neglect. This lack of emotional, social, and financial support causes strain and influences individuals to engage in deviant acts, including heroin usage.<sup id="cite_ref-righteous_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-righteous-18">[18]</a></sup> They further found that heroin users practiced "retreatism", a behavior first described by Howard Abadinsky, in which those suffering from such strain reject society's goals and institutionalized means of achieving them.<sup id="cite_ref-orgcrime_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-orgcrime-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prescription_for_addicts">Prescription for addicts</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The UK Department of Health's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rolleston_Committee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rolleston Committee (page does not exist)">Rolleston Committee</a> Report<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> in 1926 established the British approach to diacetylmorphine prescription to users, which was maintained for the next 40 years: dealers were prosecuted, but doctors could prescribe diacetylmorphine to users when withdrawing from it would cause harm or severe distress to the patient. This "policing and prescribing" policy effectively controlled the perceived diacetylmorphine problem in the UK until 1959 when the number of diacetylmorphine addicts doubled every 16 months during a period of ten years, 1959–1968.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> In 1964 the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brain_Committee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brain Committee (page does not exist)">Brain Committee</a> recommended that only selected approved doctors working at approved specialised centres be allowed to prescribe diacetylmorphine and benzoylmethylecgonine (<a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">cocaine</a>) to users. The law was made more restrictive in 1968. Beginning in the 1970s, the emphasis shifted to abstinence and the use of <a href="/wiki/Methadone" title="Methadone">methadone</a>; until now only a small number of users in the UK are prescribed diacetylmorphine.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1994, Switzerland began a trial <a href="/w/index.php?title=Heroin-assisted_treatment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Heroin-assisted treatment (page does not exist)">diamorphine maintenance</a> program for users that had failed multiple withdrawal programs. The aim of this program was to maintain the health of the user by avoiding medical problems stemming from the illicit use of diacetylmorphine. The first trial in 1994 involved 340 users, although enrollment was later expanded to 1000 based on the apparent success of the program.
</p><p>The trials proved <a href="/w/index.php?title=Heroin-assisted_treatment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Heroin-assisted treatment (page does not exist)">diamorphine maintenance</a> to be superior to other forms of treatment in improving the social and health situation for this group of patients.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> It has also been shown to save money, despite high treatment expenses, as it significantly reduces costs incurred by trials, incarceration, health interventions and <a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/delinquency" class="extiw" title="wikt:delinquency">delinquency</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p><p>Patients appear twice daily at a treatment center, where they inject their dose of diamorphine under the supervision of medical staff. They are required to contribute about 450 <a href="/wiki/Swiss_franc" title="Swiss franc">Swiss francs</a> per month to the treatment costs.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Swiss_referendum,_November_2008&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Swiss referendum, November 2008 (page does not exist)">national referendum in November 2008</a> showed 68% of voters supported the plan,<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> introducing diacetylmorphine prescription into federal law. The trials before were based on time-limited executive ordinances.
</p><p>The success of the Swiss trials led German, Dutch,<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> and Canadian<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> cities to try out their own diamorphine prescription programs.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> Some Australian cities (such as Sydney) have instituted legal diacetylmorphine <a href="/w/index.php?title=Safe_injection_site&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Safe injection site (page does not exist)">supervised injecting centers</a>, in line with other wider <a href="/wiki/Harm_minimization" title="Harm minimization" class="mw-redirect">harm minimization</a> programs.
</p><p>Since January 2009, Denmark has prescribed diamorphine to a few addicts that have tried <a href="/wiki/Methadone" title="Methadone">methadone</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Subutex&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Subutex (page does not exist)">subutex</a> without success.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> Beginning in February 2010, addicts in <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen" title="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Odense" title="Odense">Odense</a> will be eligible to receive free diacetylmorphine. Later in 2010 other cities including <a href="/wiki/%C3%85rhus" title="Århus" class="mw-redirect">Århus</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Esbjerg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Esbjerg (page does not exist)">Esbjerg</a> will join the scheme. In total, around 230 addicts will be able to receive free diacetylmorphine.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
However, Danish addicts will only be able to inject heroin according to the policy set by Danish National Board of Health.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> Of the estimated 1500 drug users who do not benefit from the current oral substitution treatment, approximately 900 will not be in the target group for treatment with injectable diacetylmorphine, either because of "massive multiple drug abuse of non-opioids" or "not wanting treatment with injectable diacetylmorphine".<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2009, the German <a href="/wiki/Bundestag" title="Bundestag">Bundestag</a> passed a law allowing diacetylmorphine prescription as a standard treatment for addicts; a large-scale trial of diacetylmorphine prescription had been authorized in that country in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Detection_in_biological_fluids">Detection in biological fluids</span></h3>
<p>The major metabolites of diacetylmorphine, 6-MAM, morphine, morphine-3-glucuronide and morphine-6-glucuronide, may be quantitated in blood, plasma or urine to monitor for abuse, confirm a diagnosis of poisoning or assist in a medicolegal death investigation. Most commercial opiate screening tests cross-react appreciably with these metabolites, as well as with other biotransformation products likely to be present following usage of street-grade diacetylmorphine such as 6-acetylcodeine and codeine. However, chromatographic techniques can easily distinguish and measure each of these substances. When interpreting the results of a test, it is important to consider the diacetylmorphine usage history of the individual, since a chronic user can develop tolerance to doses that would incapacitate an opiate-naive individual, and the chronic user often has high baseline values of these metabolites in his system. Furthermore, some testing procedures employ a hydrolysis step prior to quantitation that converts many of the metabolic products to morphine, yielding a result that may be 2 times larger than with a method that examines each product individually.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Adverse_effects">Adverse effects</span></h2>
<p>Like most <a href="/wiki/Opioids" title="Opioids" class="mw-redirect">opioids</a>, unadulterated heroin does not cause many long-term complications other than <a href="/wiki/Physical_dependence" title="Physical dependence">dependence</a> and <a href="/wiki/Constipation" title="Constipation">constipation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup>  The average purity of street heroin in the UK varies between 30% and 50% and heroin that has been seized at the border has purity levels between 40% and 60%; this variation has led to people suffering from overdoses as a result of the heroin missing a stage on its journey from port to end user, as each set of hands that the drug passes through adds further adulterants, the strength of the drug reduces, with the effect that if steps are missed, the purity of the drug reaching the end user is higher than they are used to and because they are unable to tolerate the increase, an overdose ensues.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Intravenous" title="Intravenous" class="mw-redirect">Intravenous</a> use of heroin (and any other substance) with non-sterile needles and syringes or other related equipment may lead to:
</p>
<ul>
<li>The risk of contracting blood-borne <a href="/wiki/Pathogens" title="Pathogens" class="mw-redirect">pathogens</a> such as HIV and <a href="/wiki/Hepatitis" title="Hepatitis">hepatitis</a> by the sharing of needles
</li>
<li>The risk of contracting bacterial or fungal <a href="/wiki/Endocarditis" title="Endocarditis">endocarditis</a> and possibly venous sclerosis
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Abscesses" title="Abscesses" class="mw-redirect">Abscesses</a>
</li>
<li>Poisoning from <a href="/wiki/Contaminants" title="Contaminants" class="mw-redirect">contaminants</a> added to "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Cutting_agent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cutting agent (page does not exist)">cut</a>" or dilute heroin
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Physical_dependence" title="Physical dependence">Physical dependence</a> can result from prolonged use of all opioids, resulting in withdrawal symptoms on cessation of use
</li>
<li>Decreased kidney function (although it is not currently known if this is because of adulterants or infectious diseases)<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Many countries and local governments have begun funding programs that supply <a href="/wiki/Sterilization_(microbiology)" title="Sterilization (microbiology)">sterile</a> needles to people who inject illegal drugs in an attempt to reduce these contingent risks, and especially the spread of blood-borne diseases. The Drug Policy Alliance reports that up to 75% of new AIDS cases among women and children are directly or indirectly a consequence of drug use by injection .{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} The United States federal government does not operate needle exchanges, although some state and local governments do support needle exchange programs.
</p><p>Anthropologists <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philippe_Bourgois&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philippe Bourgois (page does not exist)">Philippe Bourgois</a> and Jeff Schonberg performed a decade of field work among homeless heroin and cocaine addicts in San Francisco, published in 2009. They reported that the African-American addicts they observed were more inclined to "direct deposit" heroin into a vein, while "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Skin_popping&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Skin popping (page does not exist)">skin-popping</a>" was a far more widespread practice: "By the midpoint of our fieldwork, most of the whites had given up searching for operable veins and skin-popped. They sank their needles perfunctorily, often through their clothing, into their fatty tissue.") Bourgois and Schonberg describes how the cultural difference between the African-Americans and the whites leads to this contrasting behavior, and also points out that the two different ways to inject heroin comes with different health risks. Skin-popping more often results in abscesses, and direct injection more often leads to fatal overdose and also to <a href="/wiki/Hepatitis_C" title="Hepatitis C">hepatitis C</a> and HIV infection.<sup id="cite_ref-righteous_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-righteous-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Heroin overdose is usually treated with an opioid <a href="/wiki/Receptor_antagonist" title="Receptor antagonist">antagonist</a>,{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} such as <a href="/wiki/Naloxone" title="Naloxone">naloxone</a> (<a href="/wiki/Narcan" title="Narcan" class="mw-redirect">Narcan</a>), or <a href="/wiki/Naltrexone" title="Naltrexone">naltrexone</a>, which has high affinity for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Opioid_receptors&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Opioid receptors (page does not exist)">opioid receptors</a> but does not activate them. This reverses the effects of heroin and other opioid agonists and causes an immediate return of consciousness but may precipitate <a href="/wiki/Drug_withdrawal" title="Drug withdrawal">withdrawal</a> symptoms. The <a href="/wiki/Half-life" title="Half-life">half-life</a> of <a href="/wiki/Naloxone" title="Naloxone">naloxone</a> is much shorter than that of most opioid agonists, so that antagonist typically has to be administered multiple times until the opioid has been metabolized by the body.
</p><p>Depending on drug interactions and numerous other factors, death from overdose can take anywhere from several minutes to several hours because of anoxia resulting from the breathing reflex being suppressed by agonism of <a href="/wiki/Opioid_receptor" title="Opioid receptor">µ-opioid receptors</a>. An overdose is immediately reversible with an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Opioid_antagonist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Opioid antagonist (page does not exist)">opioid antagonist</a> injection. Heroin overdoses can occur because of an unexpected increase in the dose or purity or because of diminished opioid tolerance. However, many fatalities reported as overdoses are probably caused by interactions with other <a href="/wiki/Depressant" title="Depressant">depressant</a> drugs like alcohol or <a href="/wiki/Benzodiazepine" title="Benzodiazepine">benzodiazepines</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> It should also be noted that since heroin can cause nausea and vomiting, a significant number of deaths attributed to heroin overdose are caused by aspiration of vomit by an unconscious victim. Some sources quote the <a href="/wiki/Median_lethal_dose" title="Median lethal dose">median lethal dose</a> (for an average 75&#160;kg opiate-naive individual) as being between 75 and 375&#160;mg.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> Illicit heroin is of widely varying and unpredictable purity. This means that the user may prepare what they consider to be a moderate dose while actually taking far more than intended. Also, tolerance typically decreases after a period of abstinence. If this occurs and the user takes a dose comparable to their previous use, the user may experience drug effects that are much greater than expected, potentially resulting in a dangerous overdose. It has been speculated that an unknown portion of heroin related deaths are the result of an overdose or allergic reaction to <a href="/wiki/Quinine" title="Quinine">quinine</a>, which may sometimes be used as a cutting agent.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p>A final factor contributing to overdoses is <a href="/wiki/Operant_conditioning" title="Operant conditioning">place conditioning</a>. Heroin use is a highly ritualized behavior. While the mechanism has yet to be clearly elucidated, longtime heroin users display increased tolerance to the drug in locations where they have repeatedly administered. When the user injects in a different location, this environment-conditioned tolerance does not occur, resulting in a greater drug effect. The user's typical dose of the drug, in the face of decreased tolerance, becomes far too high and can be toxic, leading to overdose.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>A small percentage of heroin smokers, and occasionally IV users, may develop symptoms of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Toxic_leukoencephalopathy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Toxic leukoencephalopathy (page does not exist)">toxic leukoencephalopathy</a>. The cause has yet to be identified, but one speculation is that the disorder is caused by an uncommon <a href="/wiki/Adulterant" title="Adulterant">adulterant</a> that is only active when heated.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> Symptoms include slurred speech and difficulty walking.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">Cocaine</a> is sometimes used in combination with heroin, and is referred to as a <a href="/wiki/Speedball_(drug)" title="Speedball (drug)">speedball</a> when injected or <i>moonrocks</i> when smoked together. Cocaine acts as a <a href="/wiki/Stimulant" title="Stimulant">stimulant</a>, whereas heroin acts as a <a href="/wiki/Depressant" title="Depressant">depressant</a>. Coadministration provides an intense rush of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Euphoria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Euphoria (page does not exist)">euphoria</a> with a high that combines both effects of the drugs, while excluding the negative effects, such as <a href="/wiki/Anxiety" title="Anxiety">anxiety</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sedation" title="Sedation">sedation</a>. The effects of cocaine wear off far more quickly than heroin, thus if an overdose of heroin was used to compensate for cocaine, the end result is fatal <a href="/wiki/Respiratory_depression" title="Respiratory depression" class="mw-redirect">respiratory depression</a>.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Heroin.JPG</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Preparing heroin for injection
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Anal Heroin.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Modified syringe for suppository administration
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Heroin Stamp.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>One stamp of heroin
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Chunkyno3.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Chunky "No.3" heroin
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Withdrawal">Withdrawal</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The withdrawal syndrome from heroin (the so-called "<a href="/wiki/Cold_turkey" title="Cold turkey">cold turkey</a>") may begin within 6 to 24 hours of discontinuation of the drug; however, this time frame can fluctuate with the degree of tolerance as well as the amount of the last consumed dose. Symptoms may include:<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweating&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweating (page does not exist)">sweating</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malaise" title="Malaise">malaise</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anxiety" title="Anxiety">anxiety</a>, depression, <a href="/wiki/Akathisia" title="Akathisia">akathisia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Priapism" title="Priapism">priapism</a>, extra sensitivity of the genitals in females, general feeling of heaviness, excessive <a href="/wiki/Yawning" title="Yawning" class="mw-redirect">yawning</a> or <a href="/wiki/Sneezing" title="Sneezing" class="mw-redirect">sneezing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tears" title="Tears">tears</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rhinorrhea" title="Rhinorrhea">rhinorrhea</a>, sleep difficulties (<a href="/wiki/Insomnia" title="Insomnia">insomnia</a>), cold sweats, chills, severe muscle and bone aches, nausea, vomiting, <a href="/wiki/Diarrhea" title="Diarrhea">diarrhea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cramps" title="Cramps" class="mw-redirect">cramps</a>, watery eyes,<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> fever and cramp-like pains and involuntary spasms in the limbs (thought to be an origin of the term "kicking the habit"<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>).
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Pharmacology">Pharmacology</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Heroin_black_tar.jpg" title="File:Heroin black tar.jpg">File:Heroin black tar.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Black_tar_heroin" title="Black tar heroin">Black tar heroin</a></div></div></div>
<p>When taken orally, heroin undergoes extensive <a href="/wiki/First-pass_metabolism" title="First-pass metabolism" class="mw-redirect">first-pass metabolism</a> via <a href="/wiki/Acetylation" title="Acetylation">deacetylation</a>, making it a <a href="/wiki/Prodrug" title="Prodrug">prodrug</a> for the systemic delivery of morphine.<sup id="cite_ref-Sawynok_1986_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sawynok_1986-2">[2]</a></sup> When the drug is injected, however, it avoids this first-pass effect, very rapidly crossing the <a href="/wiki/Blood%E2%80%93brain_barrier" title="Blood–brain barrier">blood–brain barrier</a> because of the presence of the acetyl groups, which render it much more <a href="/wiki/Lipophilicity" title="Lipophilicity">fat soluble</a> than morphine itself.<sup id="cite_ref-Klous_2005_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Klous_2005-49">[49]</a></sup> Once in the brain, it then is deacetylated variously into the inactive 3-monoacetylmorphine and the active <a href="/w/index.php?title=6-monoacetylmorphine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="6-monoacetylmorphine (page does not exist)">6-monoacetylmorphine</a> (6-MAM), and then to morphine, which bind to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mu_opioid_receptor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mu opioid receptor (page does not exist)">μ-opioid receptors</a>, resulting in the drug's euphoric, <a href="/wiki/Analgesia" title="Analgesia" class="mw-redirect">analgesic</a> (pain relief), and <a href="/wiki/Anxiolytic" title="Anxiolytic">anxiolytic</a> (anti-anxiety) effects; heroin itself exhibits relatively low affinity for the μ receptor.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> Unlike hydromorphone and oxymorphone, however, administered intravenously, heroin creates a larger histamine release, similar to morphine, resulting in the feeling of a greater subjective "body high" to some, but also instances of <a href="/wiki/Itch" title="Itch">pruritus</a> (itching) when they first start using.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>Both morphine and 6-MAM are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mu_opioid_receptor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mu opioid receptor (page does not exist)">μ-opioid</a> <a href="/wiki/Agonist" title="Agonist">agonists</a> that bind to receptors present throughout the brain, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spinal_cord&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spinal cord (page does not exist)">spinal cord</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gut_(zoology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gut (zoology) (page does not exist)">gut</a> of all <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">mammals</a>. The μ-opioid receptor also binds endogenous <a href="/w/index.php?title=Opioid_peptide&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Opioid peptide (page does not exist)">opioid peptides</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Beta-endorphin" title="Beta-endorphin">β-endorphin</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Leu-enkephalin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leu-enkephalin (page does not exist)">Leu-enkephalin</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Met-enkephalin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Met-enkephalin (page does not exist)">Met-enkephalin</a>. Repeated use of heroin results in a number of physiological changes, including an increase in the production of μ-opioid receptors (upregulation). {{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} These physiological alterations lead to tolerance and dependence, so that cessation of heroin use results in a set of remarkably uncomfortable symptoms including pain, anxiety, muscle spasms, and insomnia called the opioid <a href="/wiki/Drug_withdrawal" title="Drug withdrawal">withdrawal</a> syndrome. Depending on usage it has an onset four to 24 hours after the last dose of heroin. Morphine also binds to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Delta_opioid_receptor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Delta opioid receptor (page does not exist)">δ</a>- and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kappa_opioid_receptor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kappa opioid receptor (page does not exist)">κ</a>-opioid receptors.
</p><p>There is also evidence that 6-MAM binds to a subtype of μ-opioid receptors that are also activated by the morphine metabolite morphine-6β-glucuronide but not morphine itself.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> The third substype of third opioid type is the mu-3 receptor, which may be a commonality to other six-position monoesters of morphine. The contribution of these receptors to the overall pharmacology of heroin remains unknown.
</p><p>A subclass of morphine derivatives, namely the 3,6 esters of morphine, with similar effects and uses, includes the clinically used strong analgesics <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nicomorphine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nicomorphine (page does not exist)">nicomorphine</a> (Vilan), and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dipropanoylmorphine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dipropanoylmorphine (page does not exist)">dipropanoylmorphine</a>; there is also the latter's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dihydromorphine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dihydromorphine (page does not exist)">dihydromorphine</a> analogue, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Diacetyldihydromorphine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diacetyldihydromorphine (page does not exist)">diacetyldihydromorphine</a> (Paralaudin). Two other 3,6 diesters of morphine invented in 1874-5 along with diacetylmorphine, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dibenzoylmorphine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dibenzoylmorphine (page does not exist)">dibenzoylmorphine</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Acetylpropionylmorphine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Acetylpropionylmorphine (page does not exist)">acetylpropionylmorphine</a>, were made as substitutes after it was outlawed in 1925 and, therefore, sold as the first "<a href="/wiki/Designer_drugs" title="Designer drugs" class="mw-redirect">designer drugs</a>" until they were outlawed by the League of Nations in 1930.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>In 1895, the German drug company <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bayer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bayer (page does not exist)">Bayer</a> marketed diacetylmorphine as an <a href="/wiki/Over-the-counter_drug" title="Over-the-counter drug">over-the-counter drug</a> under the trademark name Heroin.<sup id="cite_ref-etymonline.com_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-etymonline.com-53">[53]</a></sup> The name was derived from the Greek word "<i><a href="/wiki/Hero" title="Hero">Heros</a></i>" because of its perceived "heroic" effects upon a user.<sup id="cite_ref-etymonline.com_53-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-etymonline.com-53">[53]</a></sup> It was developed chiefly as a <a href="/wiki/Morphine" title="Morphine">morphine</a> substitute for <a href="/wiki/Cough_medicine" title="Cough medicine">cough suppressants</a> that did not have morphine's addictive side-effects. <a href="/wiki/Morphine" title="Morphine">Morphine</a> at the time was a popular recreational drug, and Bayer wished to find a similar but non-addictive substitute to market. However, contrary to Bayer's advertising as a "non-addictive morphine substitute," heroin would soon have one of the highest rates of <a href="/wiki/Drug_addiction" title="Drug addiction" class="mw-redirect">dependence</a> among its users.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Synthesis_of_Heroin_from_Opium.svg" title="File:Synthesis of Heroin from Opium.svg">File:Synthesis of Heroin from Opium.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Synthesis of heroin from opium</div></div></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bayer_Heroin_bottle.jpg" title="File:Bayer Heroin bottle.jpg">File:Bayer Heroin bottle.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Bayer Heroin bottle</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Opium_poppy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Opium poppy (page does not exist)">opium poppy</a> was cultivated in lower <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a> as long ago as 3400 BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> The chemical analysis of <a href="/wiki/Opium" title="Opium">opium</a> in the 19th century revealed that most of its activity could be ascribed to two <a href="/wiki/Alkaloids" title="Alkaloids" class="mw-redirect">alkaloids</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Codeine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Codeine (page does not exist)">codeine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Morphine" title="Morphine">morphine</a>.
</p><p>Diacetylmorphine was first synthesized in 1874 by <a href="/w/index.php?title=C._R._Alder_Wright&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="C. R. Alder Wright (page does not exist)">C. R. Alder Wright</a>, an English chemist working at <a href="/w/index.php?title=St_Mary%27s_Hospital_(London)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="St Mary's Hospital (London) (page does not exist)">St. Mary's Hospital</a> Medical School in London. He had been experimenting with combining morphine with various acids. He boiled anhydrous morphine alkaloid with <a href="/wiki/Acetic_anhydride" title="Acetic anhydride">acetic anhydride</a> for several hours and produced a more potent, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Acetylated&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Acetylated (page does not exist)">acetylated</a> form of morphine, now called <i>diacetylmorphine</i> or <i>morphine diacetate</i>. The compound was sent to F. M. Pierce of Owens College in Manchester for analysis. Pierce told Wright:
</p>
<blockquote class="toccolours" style="float:none; padding: 10px 15px 10px 15px; display:table;"> Doses&#160;... were <a href="/wiki/Route_of_administration" title="Route of administration">subcutaneously injected</a> into young dogs and rabbits&#160;... with the following general results&#160;... great <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prostration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prostration (page does not exist)">prostration</a>, fear, and sleepiness speedily following the administration, the eyes being sensitive, and pupils constrict, considerable <a href="/wiki/Salivation" title="Salivation" class="mw-redirect">salivation</a> being produced in dogs, and slight tendency to vomiting in some cases, but no actual <a href="/wiki/Emesis" title="Emesis" class="mw-redirect">emesis</a>. <a href="/wiki/Respiration_(physiology)" title="Respiration (physiology)">Respiration</a> was at first quickened, but subsequently reduced, and the heart's action was diminished, and rendered irregular. Marked want of coordinating power over the muscular movements, and loss of power in the pelvis and hind limbs, together with a diminution of temperature in the rectum of about 4°.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
<p><br />
</p>
</blockquote>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BayerHeroin.png" title="File:BayerHeroin.png">File:BayerHeroin.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Advertisement for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bayer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bayer (page does not exist)">Bayer</a> Heroin</div></div></div>
<p>Wright's invention did not lead to any further developments, and diacetylmorphine became popular only after it was independently re-synthesized 23 years later by another chemist, <a href="/wiki/Felix_Hoffmann" title="Felix Hoffmann">Felix Hoffmann</a>. Hoffmann, working at the Aktiengesellschaft Farbenfabriken (today the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bayer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bayer (page does not exist)">Bayer</a> pharmaceutical company) in <a href="/wiki/Elberfeld" title="Elberfeld">Elberfeld</a>, Germany, was instructed by his supervisor <a href="/wiki/Heinrich_Dreser" title="Heinrich Dreser">Heinrich Dreser</a> to acetylate morphine with the objective of producing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Codeine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Codeine (page does not exist)">codeine</a>, a constituent of the opium poppy, pharmacologically similar to morphine but less potent and less addictive. Instead, the experiment produced an acetylated form of morphine one and a half to two times more potent than morphine itself. The head of Bayer's research department reputedly coined the drug's new name, "heroin," based on the German "heroisch," which means "heroic, strong.'
</p><p>From 1898 through to 1910, diacetylmorphine was marketed under the trademark name Heroin as a non-addictive morphine substitute and cough suppressant. Bayer marketed the drug as a cure for morphine addiction before it was discovered that it rapidly metabolizes into morphine. As such, diacetylmorphine is in essence a quicker-acting form of morphine. The company was embarrassed by the new finding, which became a historic blunder for Bayer.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the U.S.A., the <a href="/wiki/Harrison_Narcotics_Tax_Act" title="Harrison Narcotics Tax Act">Harrison Narcotics Tax Act</a> was passed in 1914 to control the sale and distribution of diacetylmorphine and other opioids, which allowed the drug to be prescribed and sold for medical purposes. In 1924, the United States Congress banned its sale, importation, or manufacture. It is now a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Schedule_I_controlled_substance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Schedule I controlled substance (page does not exist)">Schedule I substance</a>, which makes it illegal for non-medical use in signatory nations of the <a href="/wiki/Single_Convention_on_Narcotic_Drugs" title="Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs">Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs</a> treaty, including the United States.
</p><p>The Health Committee of the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> banned diacetylmorphine in 1925, although it took more than three years for this to be implemented. In the meantime, the first <a href="/wiki/Designer_drugs" title="Designer drugs" class="mw-redirect">designer drugs</a>, viz. 3,6 diesters and 6 monoesters of morphine and acetylated analogues of closely related drugs like <a href="/wiki/Hydromorphone" title="Hydromorphone">hydromorphone</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dihydromorphine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dihydromorphine (page does not exist)">dihydromorphine</a> were produced in massive quantities to fill the worldwide demand for diacetylmorphine—this continued until 1930 when the Committee banned diacetylmorphine analogues with no therapeutic advantage over drugs already in use, the first major legislation of this type.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>Later, as with <a href="/wiki/Aspirin" title="Aspirin">Aspirin</a>, Bayer lost some of its trademark rights to heroin under the 1919 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a> following the German defeat in <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">World War I</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Routes_of_administration">Routes of administration</span></h2>
<table border="1" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="1" style="background:#fff; float:right; width:270px; border-collapse:collapse; clear:right; margin:0 0 0 0.5em;">

<tr>
<td><b>Recreational uses:</b>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Euphoria_(emotion)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Euphoria (emotion) (page does not exist)">Euphoria</a>
</li>
<li><a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/transcendent" class="extiw" title="wiktionary:transcendent">Transcendent</a> <a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/relaxation" class="extiw" title="wiktionary:relaxation">relaxation</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><b>Medicinal uses:</b>
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Painkiller&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Painkiller (page does not exist)">Powerful analgesic</a> (pain killer)
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Cough_suppressant" title="Cough suppressant" class="mw-redirect">Cough suppressant</a>
</li>
<li>Anti-<a href="/wiki/Diarrhea" title="Diarrhea">diarrheal</a>
</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><b><a href="/wiki/Contraindication" title="Contraindication">Contraindications</a>:</b>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ethanol" title="Ethanol">Alcohol</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Barbiturate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barbiturate (page does not exist)">Barbiturates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Benzodiazepines" title="Benzodiazepines" class="mw-redirect">benzodiazepines</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Stimulant" title="Stimulant">Stimulants</a>
</li>
<li>Other <a href="/wiki/Opioid" title="Opioid">opioids</a>
</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><i><b>Central nervous system:</b></i>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Drowsiness&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Drowsiness (page does not exist)">Drowsiness</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Disorientation" title="Disorientation" class="mw-redirect">Disorientation</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Delirium" title="Delirium">Delirium</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><i><b>Neurological:</b></i>
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Analgesia" title="Analgesia" class="mw-redirect">Analgesia</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Drug_tolerance" title="Drug tolerance">Tolerance</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Drug_addiction" title="Drug addiction" class="mw-redirect">Addiction (physical dependence)</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><i><b>Psychological:</b></i>
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Psychological_drug_tolerance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Psychological drug tolerance (page does not exist)">Addiction (psychological dependence)</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Anxiolysis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anxiolysis (page does not exist)">Anxiolysis</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Confusion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Confusion (page does not exist)">Confusion</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Euphoria_(emotion)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Euphoria (emotion) (page does not exist)">Euphoria</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Somnolence" title="Somnolence">Somnolence</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><i><b>Cardiovascular &amp; Respiratory:</b></i>
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bradycardia" title="Bradycardia">Bradycardia</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Hypotension" title="Hypotension">Hypotension</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Hypoventilation" title="Hypoventilation">Hypoventilation</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Shallow_breathing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shallow breathing (page does not exist)">Shallow breathing</a>
</li>
<li>Respiratory depression
</li>
</ul>
<p><i><b>Gastrointestinal:</b></i>
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nausea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nausea (page does not exist)">Nausea</a>
</li>
<li><a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/protracted" class="extiw" title="wiktionary:protracted">Protracted</a> vomiting
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Constipation" title="Constipation">Constipation</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Dyspepsia" title="Dyspepsia">Dyspepsia</a> (heartburn)
</li>
</ul>
<p><i><b>Musculoskeletal:</b></i>
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Analgesia" title="Analgesia" class="mw-redirect">Analgesia</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ataxia" title="Ataxia">Ataxia</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Muscle_spasticity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Muscle spasticity (page does not exist)">Muscle spasticity</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><i><b>Skin:</b></i>
</p>
<ul>
<li>Itching
</li>
<li>Flushing/Rash
</li>
</ul>
<p><i><b>Miscellaneous:</b></i>
</p>
<ul>
<li>Dry mouth (<a href="/wiki/Xerostomia" title="Xerostomia">xerostomia</a>)
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Miosis" title="Miosis">Miosis</a> (pupil constriction)
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Urinary_retention" title="Urinary retention">Urinary retention</a>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Diamorphine_ampoules.JPG" title="File:Diamorphine ampoules.JPG">File:Diamorphine ampoules.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Diamorphine ampoules for medicinal use</div></div></div>
</td></tr></table>
<p>The onset of heroin's effects depends upon the <a href="/wiki/Route_of_administration" title="Route of administration">route of administration</a>. Studies have shown that the subjective pleasure of drug use (the reinforcing component of addiction) is proportional to the rate at which the blood level of the drug increases.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> Intravenous injection is the fastest route of drug administration, causing blood concentrations to rise the most quickly, followed by smoking, <a href="/wiki/Suppository" title="Suppository">suppository</a> (anal or vaginal insertion), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Insufflation_(medicine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Insufflation (medicine) (page does not exist)">insufflation</a> (snorting), and <a href="/wiki/Ingestion" title="Ingestion">ingestion</a> (swallowing).
</p><p>Ingestion does not produce a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rush_(psychology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rush (psychology) (page does not exist)">rush</a> as forerunner to the high experienced with the use of heroin, which is most pronounced with intravenous use. While the onset of the rush induced by injection can occur in as little as a few seconds, the oral route of administration requires approximately half an hour before the high sets in. Thus, with both higher the dosage of heroin used and faster the route of administration used, the higher potential risk for psychological addiction.
</p><p><span class="nowrap">Large doses of heroin</span> can cause fatal respiratory depression, and the drug has been used for suicide or as a murder weapon. The serial killer <a href="/wiki/Harold_Shipman" title="Harold Shipman">Dr Harold Shipman</a> used diamorphine on his victims, and the subsequent "Shipman Inquiry" led to a tightening of the regulations surrounding the storage, prescribing and destruction of controlled drugs in the UK. <a href="/wiki/John_Bodkin_Adams" title="John Bodkin Adams">Dr John Bodkin Adams</a> (see his victim <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edith_Alice_Morrell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edith Alice Morrell (page does not exist)">Edith Alice Morrell</a>) is also known to have used heroin as a murder weapon.
</p><p>Because significant tolerance to respiratory depression develops quickly with continued use and is lost just as quickly during withdrawal, it is often difficult to determine whether a heroin lethal overdose was accidental, suicide or homicide. Examples include the overdose deaths of <a href="/wiki/Sid_Vicious" title="Sid Vicious">Sid Vicious</a>, <a href="/wiki/Janis_Joplin" title="Janis Joplin">Janis Joplin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tim_Buckley" title="Tim Buckley">Tim Buckley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hillel_Slovak" title="Hillel Slovak">Hillel Slovak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Layne_Staley" title="Layne Staley">Layne Staley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bradley_Nowell" title="Bradley Nowell">Bradley Nowell</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ted_Binion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ted Binion (page does not exist)">Ted Binion</a>, and <a href="/wiki/River_Phoenix" title="River Phoenix">River Phoenix</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chronic use of heroin and other opioids, has been shown to be a potential cause of <a href="/wiki/Hyponatremia" title="Hyponatremia">hyponatremia</a>, resultant because of excess <a href="/wiki/Vasopressin" title="Vasopressin">vasopressin</a> secretion.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Oral">Oral</span></h3>
<p>Oral use of heroin is less common than other methods of administration, mainly because there is little to no "rush", and the effects are less potent.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> Heroin is entirely converted to <a href="/wiki/Morphine" title="Morphine">morphine</a> by means of <a href="/wiki/First-pass_metabolism" title="First-pass metabolism" class="mw-redirect">first-pass metabolism</a>, resulting in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Deacetylation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deacetylation (page does not exist)">deacetylation</a> when ingested. Heroin's oral bioavailability is both dose-dependent (as is morphine's) and significantly higher than oral use of morphine itself, reaching up to 64.2% for high doses and 45.6% for low doses; opiate-naive users showed far less absorption of the drug at low doses, having bioavailabilities of only up to 22.9%. The maximum plasma concentration of morphine following oral administration of heroin was around twice as much as that of oral morphine.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Injection">Injection</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Drug_injection&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Drug injection (page does not exist)">Injection</a>, also known as "slamming", "banging", "shooting up", "digging" or "mainlining", is a popular method which carries relatively greater risks than other methods of administration. Heroin base (commonly found in Europe), when prepared for injection will only dissolve in water when mixed with an acid (most commonly citric acid powder or lemon juice) and heated. Heroin in the East coast United States is most commonly found in the hydrochloride salt form, requiring just water (and no heat) to dissolve. Users tend to initially inject in the easily accessible arm veins, but as these veins collapse over time, users resort to more dangerous areas of the body, such as the <a href="/wiki/Femoral_vein" title="Femoral vein">femoral vein</a> in the groin. Users who have used this route of administration often develop a <a href="/wiki/Deep_vein_thrombosis" title="Deep vein thrombosis">deep vein thrombosis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> Intravenous users can use a various single dose range using a <a href="/wiki/Hypodermic_needle" title="Hypodermic needle">hypodermic needle</a>. The dose of heroin used for recreational purposes is dependent on the frequency and level of use, thus a first-time user may use between 5 and 20&#160;mg, while an established addict may require several hundred mg per day. As with the injection of any drug, if a group of users <a href="/wiki/Needle_sharing" title="Needle sharing">share a common needle</a> without sterilization procedures, blood-borne diseases, such as HIV or <a href="/wiki/Hepatitis" title="Hepatitis">hepatitis</a>, can be transmitted.
The use of a common dispenser for water for the use in the preparation of the injection, as well as the sharing of spoons and/or filters can also cause the spread of blood borne diseases. Many countries now supply small sterile spoons and filters for single use in order to prevent the spread of disease.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Smoking">Smoking</span></h3>
<p>Smoking heroin refers to vaporizing it to inhale the resulting fumes, not burning it to inhale the resulting smoke. It is commonly smoked in glass pipes made from <a href="/wiki/Glassblowing" title="Glassblowing">glassblown</a> <a href="/wiki/Pyrex" title="Pyrex">Pyrex tubes</a> and light bulbs. It can also be smoked off aluminium foil, which is heated underneath by a flame and the resulting smoke is inhaled through a tube of rolled up foil, This method is also known as "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Chasing_the_dragon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chasing the dragon (page does not exist)">chasing the dragon</a>" (whereas smoking <a href="/w/index.php?title=Methamphetamine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Methamphetamine (page does not exist)">methamphetamine</a> is known as "chasing the <i>white</i> dragon").
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Insufflation">Insufflation</span></h3>
<p>Another popular route to intake heroin is <a href="/wiki/Insufflation" title="Insufflation">insufflation</a> (snorting), where a user crushes the heroin into a fine powder and then gently inhales it (sometimes with a straw or a rolled up <a href="/wiki/Banknote" title="Banknote">banknote</a>, as with <a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">cocaine</a>) into the nose, where heroin is absorbed through the soft tissue in the <a href="/wiki/Mucous_membrane" title="Mucous membrane">mucous membrane</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Sinus_cavity" title="Sinus cavity" class="mw-redirect">sinus cavity</a> and straight into the bloodstream. This method of administration redirects <a href="/wiki/First_pass_metabolism" title="First pass metabolism" class="mw-redirect">first pass metabolism</a>, with a quicker onset and higher <a href="/wiki/Bioavailability" title="Bioavailability">bioavailability</a> than oral administration, though the duration of action is shortened. This method is sometimes preferred by users who do not want to prepare and administer heroin for injection or smoking, but still experience a fast onset. Snorting heroin becomes an often unwanted route, once a user begins to inject the drug. The user may still get high on the drug from snorting, and experience a nod, but will not get a rush. A "rush" is caused by a large amount of heroin entering the body at once. When the drug is taken in through the nose, the user does not get the rush because the drug is absorbed slowly rather than instantly.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Suppository">Suppository</span></h3>
<p>Little research has been focused on the <a href="/wiki/Suppository" title="Suppository">suppository</a> (anal insertion) or <a href="/wiki/Pessary" title="Pessary">pessary</a> (vaginal insertion) methods of administration, also known as "plugging". These methods of administration are commonly carried out using an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oral_syringe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oral syringe (page does not exist)">oral syringe</a>. Heroin can be dissolved and withdrawn into an oral syringe which may then be lubricated and inserted into the anus or vagina before the plunger is pushed. The rectum or the vaginal canal is where the majority of the drug would likely be taken up, through the membranes lining their walls.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Regulation">Regulation</span></h2>
<p>In the Netherlands, diacetylmorphine is a List I drug of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Opium_Law&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Opium Law (page does not exist)">Opium Law</a>. It is available for prescription under tight regulation exclusively to long-term addicts for whom <a href="/w/index.php?title=Methadone_maintenance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Methadone maintenance (page does not exist)">methadone maintenance</a> treatment has failed. It cannot be used to treat severe <a href="/wiki/Pain" title="Pain">pain</a> or other illnesses.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the United States, diacetylmorphine is a schedule I drug according to the <a href="/wiki/Controlled_Substances_Act" title="Controlled Substances Act">Controlled Substances Act</a> of 1970, making it illegal to possess without a DEA license.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> Possession of more than 100&#160;grams of diacetylmorphine or a mixture containing diacetylmorphine is punishable with a minimum mandatory sentence of 5 years of imprisonment in a federal prison.
</p><p>In Canada, diacetylmorphine is a controlled substance<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> under Schedule I of the <a href="/wiki/Controlled_Drugs_and_Substances_Act" title="Controlled Drugs and Substances Act">Controlled Drugs and Substances Act</a> (CDSA).<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> Any person seeking or obtaining diacetylmorphine without disclosing authorization 30 days prior to obtaining another prescription from a practitioner is guilty of an indictable offense and subject to imprisonment for a term not exceeding seven years. Possession of diacetylmorphine for the purpose of trafficking is an indictable offense and subject to imprisonment for life.
</p><p>In Hong Kong, diacetylmorphine is regulated under Schedule 1 of <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>'s Chapter 134 <i>Dangerous Drugs Ordinance</i>. It is available by prescription. Anyone supplying diacetylmorphine without a valid prescription can be fined $10,000 (<a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong_dollar" title="Hong Kong dollar">HKD</a>). The penalty for trafficking or manufacturing diacetylmorphine is a $50,000 (HKD) fine and life imprisonment. Possession of diacetylmorphine without a license from the Department of Health is illegal with a $10,000 (HKD) fine and/or 7 years of jail time.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the United Kingdom, diacetylmorphine is available by prescription, though it is a restricted <a href="/wiki/Class_A_drug" title="Class A drug" class="mw-redirect">Class A drug</a>. According to the 50th edition of the <a href="/wiki/British_National_Formulary" title="British National Formulary">British National Formulary</a> (BNF), diamorphine <a href="/wiki/Hydrochloride" title="Hydrochloride">hydrochloride</a> may be used in the treatment of acute pain, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Myocardial_infarction&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Myocardial infarction (page does not exist)">myocardial infarction</a>, acute <a href="/wiki/Pulmonary_oedema" title="Pulmonary oedema" class="mw-redirect">pulmonary oedema</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chronic_pain" title="Chronic pain">chronic pain</a>.
