The treatment of chronic non-<a href="/w/index.php?title=Malignant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Malignant (page does not exist)">malignant</a> pain must be supervised by a specialist. The BNF notes that all opioid analgesics cause dependence and tolerance but that this is "no deterrent in the control of pain in terminal illness". When used in the <a href="/wiki/Palliative_care" title="Palliative care">palliative care</a> of cancer patients, diacetylmorphine is often injected using a <a href="/wiki/Syringe_driver" title="Syringe driver">syringe driver</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Production_and_trafficking">Production and trafficking</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Production">Production</span></h3>
<p>Diacetylmorphine is produced from acetylation of morphine derived from natural opium sources. Numerous mechanical and chemical means are used to purify the final product. The final products have a different appearance depending on purity and have different names.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Heroin_grades">Heroin grades</span></h3>
<p>Heroin purity has been classified into four grades. No.4 is the purest form – white powder (salt) to be easily dissolved and injected. No.3 is "brown sugar" for smoking (base). No.1 and No.2 are unprocessed raw heroin (salt or base).<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Trafficking">Trafficking</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Drugroutemap.gif" title="File:Drugroutemap.gif">File:Drugroutemap.gif</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">International drug routes</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Traffic is heavy worldwide, with the biggest producer being Afghanistan.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> According to a U.N. sponsored survey,<sup id="cite_ref-UNODCSurvey_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNODCSurvey-4">[4]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, Afghanistan accounted for production of 87 percent of the world's diacetylmorphine.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> Afghan opium kills around 100,000 people annually.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>The cultivation of opium in Afghanistan reached its peak in 1999, when <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of poppies were sown. The following year the Taliban banned poppy cultivation, a move which cut production by 94 percent. By 2001 only <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of land were in use for growing opium poppies. A year later, after American and British troops had removed the Taliban and installed the interim government, the land under cultivation leapt back to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, with Afghanistan supplanting Burma to become the world's largest opium producer once more.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup>
Opium production in that country has increased rapidly since, reaching an all-time high in 2006. <a href="/w/index.php?title=War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="War in Afghanistan (2001–present) (page does not exist)">War in Afghanistan</a> once again appeared as a facilitator of the trade.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> Some 3.3 million Afghans are involved in producing opium.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>At present, opium poppies are mostly grown in <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, and in Southeast Asia, especially in the region known as the Golden Triangle straddling <a href="/wiki/Burma" title="Burma">Burma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yunnan" title="Yunnan">Yunnan</a> province in China. There is also cultivation of opium poppies in the <a href="/wiki/Sinaloa" title="Sinaloa">Sinaloa</a> region of Mexico and in <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>. The majority of the heroin consumed in the United States comes from Mexico and <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} Up until 2004, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> was considered<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:By_whom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:By whom (page does not exist)">Template:By whom</a> one of the biggest opium-growing countries.
</p><p>Conviction for trafficking heroin carries the death penalty in most <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asian" title="Southeast Asian" class="mw-redirect">Southeast Asian</a>, some <a href="/wiki/East_Asian" title="East Asian" class="mw-redirect">East Asian</a> and Middle Eastern countries (see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Use_of_death_penalty_worldwide&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Use of death penalty worldwide (page does not exist)">Use of death penalty worldwide</a> for details), among which <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malaysia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Malaysia (page does not exist)">Malaysia</a>, Singapore and <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a> are the most strict. The penalty applies even to citizens of countries where the penalty is not in place, sometimes causing controversy when foreign visitors are arrested for trafficking, for example the arrest of <a href="/wiki/Bali_Nine" title="Bali Nine">nine Australians in Bali</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Death_sentence" title="Death sentence" class="mw-redirect">death sentence</a> given to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nola_Blake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nola Blake (page does not exist)">Nola Blake</a> in Thailand in 1987, or the hanging of an Australian citizen <a href="/w/index.php?title=Van_Tuong_Nguyen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Van Tuong Nguyen (page does not exist)">Van Tuong Nguyen</a> in Singapore.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Trafficking_history">Trafficking history</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:HeroinWorld-en.svg" title="File:HeroinWorld-en.svg">File:HeroinWorld-en.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Primary worldwide producers of heroin</div></div></div>
<p>The origins of the present international illegal heroin trade can be traced back to laws passed in many countries in the early 1900s that closely regulated the production and sale of opium and its derivatives including heroin. At first, heroin flowed from countries where it was still legal into countries where it was no longer legal. By the mid-1920s, heroin production had been made illegal in many parts of the world. An illegal trade developed at that time between heroin labs in China (mostly in Shanghai and Tianjin) and other nations. The weakness of government in China and conditions of civil war enabled heroin production to take root there. Chinese <a href="/w/index.php?title=Triad_society&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Triad society (page does not exist)">triad</a> gangs eventually came to play a major role in the illicit heroin trade. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=French_Connection&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="French Connection (page does not exist)">French Connection</a> route started in the 1930s.
</p><p>Heroin trafficking was virtually eliminated in the U.S. during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> because of temporary trade disruptions caused by the war. Japan's war with China had cut the normal distribution routes for heroin and the war had generally disrupted the movement of opium.
</p><p>After World War II, the <a href="/wiki/Mafia" title="Mafia">Mafia</a> took advantage of the weakness of the postwar Italian government and set up heroin labs in Sicily. The Mafia took advantage of Sicily's location along the historic route opium took westward into Europe and the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p><p>Large-scale international heroin production effectively ended in China with the victory of the communists in the civil war in the late 1940s.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} The elimination of Chinese production happened at the same time that Sicily's role in the trade developed.
</p><p>Although it remained legal in some countries until after World War II, health risks, addiction, and widespread recreational use led most western countries to declare heroin a controlled substance by the latter half of the 20th century.
</p><p>In late 1960s and early 1970s, the <a href="/wiki/CIA" title="CIA" class="mw-redirect">CIA</a> supported anti-Communist Chinese Nationalists settled near the <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">Sino</a>-Burmese border and <a href="/wiki/Hmong_people" title="Hmong people">Hmong</a> tribesmen in <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a>. This helped the development of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Golden_Triangle_(Southeast_Asia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Golden Triangle (Southeast Asia) (page does not exist)">Golden Triangle</a> opium production region, which supplied about one-third of heroin consumed in US after the 1973 American withdrawal from Vietnam. As of 1999, Burma, the heartland of the Golden Triangle remained the second largest producer of heroin, after <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Afghan_Burmese_heroin_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Afghan_Burmese_heroin-82">[82]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Soviet-Afghan war led to increased production in the Pakistani-Afghan border regions, as U.S.-backed <a href="/wiki/Mujaheddin" title="Mujaheddin" class="mw-redirect">mujaheddin</a> militants raised money for arms from selling opium, contributing heavily to the modern <a href="/wiki/Golden_Crescent" title="Golden Crescent">Golden Crescent</a> creation. By 1980, 60% of heroin sold in the U.S. originated in Afghanistan.<sup id="cite_ref-Afghan_Burmese_heroin_82-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Afghan_Burmese_heroin-82">[82]</a></sup> It increased international production of heroin at lower prices in the 1980s. The trade shifted away from Sicily in the late 1970s as various criminal organizations violently fought with each other over the trade. The fighting also led to a stepped up government law enforcement presence in Sicily.
Following the discovery at a Jordanian airport of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Toner_cartridge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Toner cartridge (page does not exist)">toner cartridge</a> that had been modified into an <a href="/wiki/Improvised_explosive_device" title="Improvised explosive device">improvised explosive device</a>, the resultant increased level of airfreight scrutiny led to a major shortage (drought) of heroin from October 2010 until April 2011. This was reported in most of mainland Europe and the UK which led to a price increase of approx 30% in the cost of street heroin and an increased demand for diverted <a href="/wiki/Methadone" title="Methadone">methadone</a>. The number of addicts seeking treatment also increased significantly during this period.
Other Heroin droughts (shortages) have been attributed to cartels restricting supply in order to force a price increase and also to a fungus that attacked the opium crop of 2009. Many people thought that the American Government had introduced pathogens into the Afghanistan atmosphere in order to destroy the opium crop and thus starve insurgents of income.
</p><p>According to the 2009 report by the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Office_on_Drugs_and_Crime" title="United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime">United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime</a> (UNODC), <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> is both the largest producer and consumer of heroin with a value of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:INR&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:INR (page does not exist)">Template:INR</a>60&#160;billion (US$1.4 billion).<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 13 March 2012, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Haji_Bagcho&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Haji Bagcho (page does not exist)">Haji Bagcho</a>, with ties to the <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a> was convicted, by a U.S. District Court of conspiracy, distribution of heroin for importation into the United States and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Narco-terrorism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Narco-terrorism (page does not exist)">narco-terrorism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-justice2006_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-justice2006-85">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-surfky1_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-surfky1-86">[86]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-foster1_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-foster1-87">[87]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tucker1_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tucker1-88">[88]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tucker1_88-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tucker1-88">[88]</a></sup> Based on heroin production statistics<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> compiled by the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Office_on_Drugs_and_Crime" title="United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime">United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime</a>, in 2006, Bagcho's activities accounted for approximately 20% of the world's total production for that year.<sup id="cite_ref-justice2006_85-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-justice2006-85">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-surfky1_86-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-surfky1-86">[86]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-foster1_87-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-foster1-87">[87]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tucker1_88-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tucker1-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Street_price">Street price</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_Monitoring_Centre_for_Drugs_and_Drug_Addiction&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (page does not exist)">European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction</a> reports that the retail price of brown heroin varies from €14.5 per gram in Turkey to €110 per gram in Sweden, with most European countries reporting typical prices of €35–40 per gram. The price of white heroin is reported only by a few European countries and ranged between €27 and €110 per gram.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Office_on_Drugs_and_Crime" title="United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime">United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime</a> claims in its 2008 World Drug Report that typical US retail prices are US$172 per gram.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Harm_reduction">Harm reduction</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rational_scale_to_assess_the_harm_of_drugs_(mean_physical_harm_and_mean_dependence).svg" title="File:Rational scale to assess the harm of drugs (mean physical harm and mean dependence).svg">File:Rational scale to assess the harm of drugs (mean physical harm and mean dependence).svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Data from <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lancet" title="The Lancet">The Lancet</a></i> shows diacetylmorphine to be the most addictive and most harmful of twenty popular <a href="/wiki/Recreational_drugs" title="Recreational drugs" class="mw-redirect">recreational drugs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Nutt_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nutt-92">[92]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Harm_reduction" title="Harm reduction">Harm reduction</a> is a public health philosophy that seeks to reduce the harms associated with the use of diacetylmorphine. One aspect of harm reduction initiatives focuses on the behaviour of individual users. This includes promoting safer means of taking the drug, such as smoking, nasal use, oral or rectal insertion. This attempts to avoid the higher risks of overdose, infections and <a href="/wiki/Blood-borne_disease" title="Blood-borne disease">blood-borne viruses</a> associated with injecting the drug. Other measures include using a small amount of the drug first to gauge the strength, and minimize the risks of overdose. For the same reason, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Poly_drug_use&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Poly drug use (page does not exist)">poly drug use</a> (the use of two or more drugs at the same time) is discouraged. Injecting diacetylmorphine users are encouraged to use new needles, syringes, spoons/steri-cups and filters every time they inject and not share these with other users. Users are also encouraged to not use it on their own, as others can assist in the event of an overdose.
</p><p>Governments that support a harm reduction approach usually fund <a href="/w/index.php?title=Needle-exchange_programme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Needle-exchange programme (page does not exist)">needle &amp; syringe exchange programmes</a>, which supply new needles and syringes on a confidential basis, as well as education on proper filtering prior to injection, safer injection techniques, safe disposal of used injecting gear and other equipment used when preparing diacetylmorphine for injection may also be supplied including citric acid sachets/vitamin C sachets, steri-cups, filters, alcohol pre-injection swabs, sterile water ampules and tourniquets (to stop use of shoe laces or belts).
</p><p>Another harm reduction measure employed for example in Europe, Canada and Australia are <a href="/wiki/Safe_injection_sites" title="Safe injection sites" class="mw-redirect">safe injection sites</a> where users can inject diacetylmorphine and <a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">cocaine</a> under the supervision of medically trained staff. Safe injection sites are low threshold and allow social services to approach problem users that would otherwise be hard to reach.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup>
In the UK the Criminal Justice System has a protocol in place that requires that any individual that is arrested and is suspected of having a substance misuse problem, be offered the chance to enter a treatment program. This has had the effect of drastically reducing an area's crime rate as individuals arrested for theft in order to supply the funds for their drugs are no longer in the position of having to steal to purchase Heroin because they have been placed onto a <a href="/wiki/Methadone" title="Methadone">Methadone</a> program, quite often quicker than would have been possible had they not been arrested. This aspect of harm reduction is seen as being beneficial to both the individual and the community at large, who are then protected from the possible theft of their goods.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the late 1980s and early 1990s, Swiss authorities ran the ZIPP-AIDS (Zurich Intervention Pilot Project), handing out free syringes in the officially tolerated drug scene in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Platzspitz_park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Platzspitz park (page does not exist)">Platzspitz park</a>.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Popular_culture">Popular culture</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Actors">Actors</span></h3>
<p>A number of actors have been known for their use of heroin. Among them are:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/John_Belushi" title="John Belushi">John Belushi</a>,died of a <a href="/wiki/Speedball_(drug)" title="Speedball (drug)">speedball</a> overdose (cocaine and heroin) in 1982.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Chris_Farley" title="Chris Farley">Chris Farley</a>, died of a <a href="/wiki/Speedball_(drug)" title="Speedball (drug)">speedball</a> overdose (cocaine and heroin) in 1997.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/River_Phoenix" title="River Phoenix">River Phoenix</a>, died of an overdose of heroin and cocaine in 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Del_Close" title="Del Close">Del Close</a> also a director, who stopped using about two decades before he passed in 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Robert_Downey,_Jr." title="Robert Downey, Jr.">Robert Downey, Jr.</a>, clean since July 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artie_Lange&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Artie Lange (page does not exist)">Artie Lange</a><sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Mackenzie_Phillips" title="Mackenzie Phillips">Mackenzie Phillips</a><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Tom_Sizemore" title="Tom Sizemore">Tom Sizemore</a><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cory_Monteith&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cory Monteith (page does not exist)">Cory Monteith</a>, died of an overdose of heroin and alcohol in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Philip_Seymour_Hoffman" title="Philip Seymour Hoffman">Philip Seymour Hoffman</a>, died of an overdose February 2, 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Film_and_television">Film and television</span></h3>
<ul>
<li>The film <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Panic_in_Needle_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Panic in Needle Park (page does not exist)">The Panic in Needle Park</a> starring <a href="/wiki/Al_Pacino" title="Al Pacino">Al Pacino</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kitty_Winn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kitty Winn (page does not exist)">Kitty Winn</a> is the story of a young woman who falls in love with a heroin addict in New York. It was one of Pacino's first roles.
</li>
<li>The Film <a href="/wiki/Lady_Sings_the_Blues_(film)" title="Lady Sings the Blues (film)">Lady Sings the Blues</a> about the life of <a href="/wiki/Billie_Holiday" title="Billie Holiday">Billie Holiday</a> starring <a href="/wiki/Diana_Ross" title="Diana Ross">Diana Ross</a>.
</li>
<li>The Film <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bird_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bird (film) (page does not exist)">Bird</a> about the life of <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Parker" title="Charlie Parker">Charlie Parker</a> starring <a href="/wiki/Forest_Whitaker" title="Forest Whitaker">Forest Whitaker</a>, directed by <a href="/wiki/Clint_Eastwood" title="Clint Eastwood">Clint Eastwood</a>.
</li>
<li> The film, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Gangster_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Gangster (film) (page does not exist)">American Gangster</a></i>, is loosely based on real life drug dealer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frank_Lucas_(drug_lord)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frank Lucas (drug lord) (page does not exist)">Frank Lucas</a>, who sold heroin. Lucas was portrayed by <a href="/wiki/Denzel_Washington" title="Denzel Washington">Denzel Washington</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> The film <i><a href="/wiki/Gia" title="Gia">Gia</a></i>, based on a true story of model <a href="/wiki/Gia_Carangi" title="Gia Carangi">Gia Carangi</a>, is about her addiction and use of heroin and how it affected her.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> The film <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christiane_F._%E2%80%93_Wir_Kinder_vom_Bahnhof_Zoo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christiane F. – Wir Kinder vom Bahnhof Zoo (page does not exist)">Christiane F. – Wir Kinder vom Bahnhof Zoo</a>(We the children of Bahnof Zoo) is about heroin use and street culture in West Berlin in the 1970s, centering on a 13-year-old girl's decision to experiment with the drug.
</li>
<li> The film <i><a href="/wiki/Trainspotting_(film)" title="Trainspotting (film)">Trainspotting</a></i> chronicles the exploits of a group of heroin addicts in Edinburgh, Scotland, during the late 1980s.
</li>
<li> The film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Requiem_for_a_Dream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Requiem for a Dream (page does not exist)">Requiem for a Dream</a></i>, tells the story of four drug addicts (mainly heroin) who can only witness their disastrous habits spiral out of control into the darkest, ugliest and dirtiest sides of humanity.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> In <a href="/w/index.php?title=24_(season_3)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="24 (season 3) (page does not exist)">Season three</a> of the American television series <a href="/w/index.php?title=24_(TV_Series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="24 (TV Series) (page does not exist)">24</a>, the show's protagonist <a href="/wiki/Jack_Bauer" title="Jack Bauer">Jack Bauer</a> is seen battling a heroin addiction after having spent months undercover working with a drug lord family in Mexico.
</li>
<li> The film <a href="/wiki/The_Basketball_Diaries" title="The Basketball Diaries">The Basketball Diaries</a> follows protagonist Jim Carrol's addiction to heroin and getting off heroin. <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_Dicaprio" title="Leonardo Dicaprio" class="mw-redirect">Leonardo Dicaprio</a> portrayed Carroll.
</li>
<li> The American television series <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lost_(2004_TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lost (2004 TV series) (page does not exist)">Lost</a> featured a character named <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Pace" title="Charlie Pace">Charlie Pace</a>, who was a bassist from a broken up band, with a heroin addiction.
</li>
<li> The film <i><a href="/wiki/Pulp_Fiction" title="Pulp Fiction">Pulp Fiction</a></i> featuring <a href="/wiki/John_Travolta" title="John Travolta">John Travolta</a> as Vincent Vega shows IV use of the drug, and <a href="/wiki/Uma_Thurman" title="Uma Thurman">Uma Thurman</a>'s character Mia Wallace overdoses.
</li>
<li> The television series <a href="/w/index.php?title=Breaking_Bad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Breaking Bad (page does not exist)">Breaking Bad</a> features <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jane_Margolis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jane Margolis (page does not exist)">Jane Margolis</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jesse_Pinkman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jesse Pinkman (page does not exist)">Jesse Pinkman</a>'s girlfriend and landlady who is in rehab for heroin usage, but gets back into using it and introduces Jesse to it, but later dies due to the combination of an overdose and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Walter_White_(Breaking_Bad)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Walter White (Breaking Bad) (page does not exist)">Walter White</a>'s refusal to save her life.
</li>
<li> The film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rush_(1991_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rush (1991 film) (page does not exist)">Rush</a></i> (1991) starring <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Jason_Leigh" title="Jennifer Jason Leigh">Jennifer Jason Leigh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jason_Patric" title="Jason Patric">Jason Patric</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sam_Elliott" title="Sam Elliott">Sam Elliott</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gregg_Allman" title="Gregg Allman">Gregg Allman</a> is a fictionalized depiction of a heroin-trade-based corruption scandal that wracked the Tyler, Texas, USA Police Department in the late seventies; undercover detective characters played by <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Jason_Leigh" title="Jennifer Jason Leigh">Ms. Leigh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jason_Patric" title="Jason Patric">Mr. Patric</a> inadvertently become heroin addicts in the process of attempting to gather evidence against the local drug dealer played by <a href="/wiki/Gregg_Allman" title="Gregg Allman">Mr. Allman</a>.
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Musicians">Musicians</span></h3>
<p>Use of heroin by jazz musicians in particular was prevalent in the 1950s and 1960s including sax legends <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Parker" title="Charlie Parker">Charlie Parker</a> and <a href="/wiki/Art_Pepper" title="Art Pepper">Art Pepper</a>, guitarist <a href="/wiki/Joe_Pass" title="Joe Pass">Joe Pass</a> and piano player/singer <a href="/wiki/Ray_Charles" title="Ray Charles">Ray Charles</a>; a "staggering number of jazz musicians were addicts".<sup id="cite_ref-MartinWaters2008_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MartinWaters2008-110">[110]</a></sup> It was also a problem with many rock musicians, particularly from the late 1960s through the 1990s. <a href="/wiki/Pete_Doherty" title="Pete Doherty">Pete Doherty</a> is also a self-confessed user of heroin.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nirvana_(band)" title="Nirvana (band)">Nirvana</a> frontman <a href="/wiki/Kurt_Cobain" title="Kurt Cobain">Kurt Cobain</a>'s heroin addiction was well documented.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pantera" title="Pantera">Pantera</a> frontman, <a href="/wiki/Phil_Anselmo" title="Phil Anselmo">Phil Anselmo</a>, turned to heroin while touring during the 1990s to cope with his back pain.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stones" title="Rolling Stones" class="mw-redirect">Rolling Stones</a> guitarist <a href="/wiki/Keith_Richards" title="Keith Richards">Keith Richards</a> was a longtime user of the drug.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Dee_Dee_Ramone" title="Dee Dee Ramone">Dee Dee Ramone</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Ramones&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Ramones (page does not exist)">The Ramones</a> died of an overdose in 2002 at age 50.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/John_Phillips_(musician)" title="John Phillips (musician)">John Phillips</a> of <a href="/wiki/The_Mamas_and_the_Papas" title="The Mamas and the Papas" class="mw-redirect">The Mamas and the Papas</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Greg_Allman" title="Greg Allman" class="mw-redirect">Greg Allman</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Allman_Brothers_Band" title="Allman Brothers Band" class="mw-redirect">Allman Brothers Band</a>. He's been clean and sober since the mid 90's.
</p><p>A notable person is <a href="/wiki/Frankie_Lymon" title="Frankie Lymon">Frankie Lymon</a>, famous for writing and singing <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Why_Do_Fools_Fall_in_Love_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Why Do Fools Fall in Love (song) (page does not exist)">Why Do Fools Fall in Love</a></i>, who died of an overdose at the age of 25.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Janis_Joplin" title="Janis Joplin">Janis Joplin</a>'s official cause of death was an overdose of heroin, possibly combined with the effects of alcohol.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Nikki_Sixx" title="Nikki Sixx">Nikki Sixx</a> of <a href="/wiki/Motley_Crue" title="Motley Crue" class="mw-redirect">Motley Crue</a> almost died of heroin overdose in 1987.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Layne_Staley" title="Layne Staley">Layne Staley</a> of <a href="/wiki/Alice_in_Chains" title="Alice in Chains">Alice in Chains</a> was well known for songs about his addiction (some listed below), which ultimately caused his death in April 2002 from a <a href="/wiki/Speedball_(drug)" title="Speedball (drug)">speedball</a> (a mixture of <a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">cocaine</a> and heroin).
</p><p>Guitarist <a href="/wiki/Danny_Whitten" title="Danny Whitten">Danny Whitten</a> of <a href="/wiki/Neil_Young" title="Neil Young">Neil Young</a>'s backup band <a href="/wiki/Crazy_Horse" title="Crazy Horse">Crazy Horse</a>. He died of an overdose of <a href="/wiki/Valium" title="Valium" class="mw-redirect">Valium</a> and alcohol trying to kick his heroin habit. Neil was inspired to write <a href="/wiki/The_Needle_and_the_Damage_Done" title="The Needle and the Damage Done">The Needle and the Damage Done</a> over Whitten's death.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/The_Band" title="The Band">The Band</a> bassist <a href="/wiki/Rick_Danko" title="Rick Danko">Rick Danko</a> and blues harmonica player <a href="/wiki/Paul_Butterfield" title="Paul Butterfield">Paul Butterfield</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Nico" title="Nico">Nico</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Velvet_Underground&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Velvet Underground (page does not exist)">The Velvet Underground</a>. Entered a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Methadone_maintenance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Methadone maintenance (page does not exist)">methadone maintenance</a> program until her death in 1987
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Marianne_Faithfull" title="Marianne Faithfull">Marianne Faithfull</a> struggled with addiction, but entered re-hab in the mid 1980s and has stayed clean and sober since.
</p><p>Others include <a href="/wiki/Sid_Vicious" title="Sid Vicious">Sid Vicious</a>, the former bassist of the <a href="/wiki/Punk_rock" title="Punk rock">punk rock</a> group the <a href="/wiki/Sex_Pistols" title="Sex Pistols">Sex Pistols</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bradley_Nowell" title="Bradley Nowell">Bradley Nowell</a> from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sublime_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sublime (band) (page does not exist)">Sublime</a> who died of a heroin overdose in 1996.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Hillel_Slovak" title="Hillel Slovak">Hillel Slovak</a> of <a href="/wiki/The_Red_Hot_Chili_Peppers" title="The Red Hot Chili Peppers" class="mw-redirect">The Red Hot Chili Peppers</a> died of a heroin/cocaine mixture.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Anthony_Kiedis" title="Anthony Kiedis">Anthony Kiedis</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Frusciante" title="John Frusciante">John Frusciante</a>  also of the Chili Peppers, struggled with heroin addiction. They have since gotten clean.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Courtney_Love" title="Courtney Love">Courtney Love</a> has struggled with heroin addiction on and off for years.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Kristen_Pfaff" title="Kristen Pfaff">Kristen Pfaff</a> bassist for the band <a href="/wiki/Hole_(band)" title="Hole (band)">Hole</a> had a fatal overdose in 1994.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Songs">Songs</span></h3>
<ul>
<li> "The Needle and the Spoon" by <a href="/wiki/Lynyrd_Skynyrd" title="Lynyrd Skynyrd">Lynyrd Skynyrd</a> off their album <a href="/wiki/Second_Helping" title="Second Helping">Second Helping</a>
</li>
<li> "Cod'ine" Composed by: Buffy Sainte-Marie
</li>
<li> "Needle and Spoon" by Savoy Brown
</li>
<li> "Co'dine" (also as "Codine") song covered by <a href="/wiki/Donovan" title="Donovan">Donovan</a>
</li>
<li> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Heroin_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Heroin (song) (page does not exist)">Heroin</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=I%27m_Waiting_For_The_Man&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I'm Waiting For The Man (page does not exist)">I'm Waiting For The Man</a>" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Velvet_Underground&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Velvet Underground (page does not exist)">The Velvet Underground</a>
</li>
<li> "<a href="/wiki/The_Needle_and_the_Damage_Done" title="The Needle and the Damage Done">The Needle and the Damage Done</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Neil_Young" title="Neil Young">Neil Young</a>
</li>
<li> "<a href="/wiki/Golden_Brown" title="Golden Brown">Golden Brown</a>" by <a href="/wiki/The_Stranglers" title="The Stranglers">The Stranglers</a>
</li>
<li> "King Heroin" by <a href="/wiki/James_Brown" title="James Brown">James Brown</a>
</li>
<li> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Mr_Brownstone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mr Brownstone (page does not exist)">Mr Brownstone</a>" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Guns_N%27_Roses&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Guns N' Roses (page does not exist)">Guns N' Roses</a><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> "<a href="/wiki/Cold_Turkey" title="Cold Turkey">Cold Turkey</a>" by <a href="/wiki/John_Lennon" title="John Lennon">John Lennon</a> was about Lennon and <a href="/wiki/Yoko_Ono" title="Yoko Ono">Yoko Ono</a> going <a href="/wiki/Cold_turkey" title="Cold turkey">cold turkey</a> off of their heroin addictions.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> "<a href="/wiki/Space_Oddity_(song)" title="Space Oddity (song)">Space Oddity</a>", <a href="/wiki/David_Bowie" title="David Bowie">David Bowie</a>'s first single, was seemingly about his experience with heroin, as his 1980 single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Ashes_to_Ashes_(David_Bowie_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ashes to Ashes (David Bowie song) (page does not exist)">Ashes to Ashes</a>" included lines that refer to Major Tom as "...a junkie/strung out on heaven's high/hitting an all-time low."<sup id="cite_ref-nuaa_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nuaa-121">[121]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Two songs on the <a href="/wiki/U2" title="U2">U2</a> album <i><a href="/wiki/Rattle_and_Hum" title="Rattle and Hum">Rattle and Hum</a></i> refer to heroin use:
<ul>
<li>"<a href="/w/index.php?title=Desire_(U2_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Desire (U2 song) (page does not exist)">Desire</a>" uses heroin as a metaphor for lust, with the lyrics "She's the candle burnin' in my room/ Yeah, I'm like the needle/ The needle and spoon"
</li>
<li>"<a href="/w/index.php?title=Hawkmoon_269&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hawkmoon 269 (page does not exist)">Hawkmoon 269</a>", a song about the passionate need for one's lover, includes the lyric "Like a needle needs a vein"
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Songs such as "Junkhead", "Godsmack", "Dirt" "<a href="/wiki/Hate_to_Feel" title="Hate to Feel">Hate to Feel</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Angry_Chair&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Angry Chair (page does not exist)">Angry Chair</a>" from the album <a href="/wiki/Dirt_(Alice_in_Chains_album)" title="Dirt (Alice in Chains album)">Dirt</a>, including many others from other albums, by grunge band <a href="/wiki/Alice_in_Chains" title="Alice in Chains">Alice in Chains</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>"People Who Died" by The <a href="/wiki/Jim_Carroll" title="Jim Carroll">Jim Carroll</a> Band. Several people in the song died of heroin related causes.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Writers">Writers</span></h3>
<p>Writers known to have used heroin are:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Claude_Brown&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Claude Brown (page does not exist)">Claude Brown</a>, in  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Manchild_in_the_Promised_Land&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Manchild in the Promised Land (page does not exist)">Manchild in the Promised Land</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/William_S._Burroughs" title="William S. Burroughs">William S. Burroughs</a>, author of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Junky_(novel)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Junky (novel) (page does not exist)">Junky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Naked_Lunch" title="Naked Lunch">Naked Lunch</a> was on a longtime <a href="/wiki/Methadone" title="Methadone">methadone</a> program until his death.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Jim_Carroll" title="Jim Carroll">Jim Carroll</a> author of <a href="/wiki/The_Basketball_Diaries" title="The Basketball Diaries">The Basketball Diaries</a><sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other">Other</span></h3>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Anna_Kavan" title="Anna Kavan">Anna Kavan</a> (1901–1968)
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alice_Ormsby-Gore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alice Ormsby-Gore (page does not exist)">Alice Ormsby-Gore</a><sup id="cite_ref-Palacios_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Palacios-127">[127]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> Oil millionaire <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sir_Paul_Getty&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sir Paul Getty (page does not exist)">Sir Paul Getty</a><sup id="cite_ref-Palacios_127-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Palacios-127">[127]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Aleister_Crowley" title="Aleister Crowley">Aleister Crowley</a>, English <a href="/wiki/Occultist" title="Occultist" class="mw-redirect">occultist</a>, ceremonial magician, poet, and mountaineer.
</li>
</ul>

<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Allegations_of_CIA_drug_trafficking&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Allegations of CIA drug trafficking (page does not exist)">Allegations of CIA drug trafficking</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Opium_Wars" title="Opium Wars">Opium Wars</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Politics_of_Heroin_in_Southeast_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Politics of Heroin in Southeast Asia (page does not exist)">The Politics of Heroin in Southeast Asia</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cheese_(recreational_drug)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cheese (recreational drug) (page does not exist)">Cheese (recreational drug)</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> <i>Diary of a Drug Fiend</i> by <a href="/wiki/Aleister_Crowley" title="Aleister Crowley">Aleister Crowley</a> (1922)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/Junkie_(novel)" title="Junkie (novel)">Junkie</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/William_S._Burroughs" title="William S. Burroughs">William S. Burroughs</a> (1953) <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0142003166" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-14-200316-6</a>
</li>
<li> <i>Heroin</i> (1998) <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1568381530" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-56838-153-0</a>
</li>
<li> <i>Heroin Century</i> (2002) <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0415278996" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-415-27899-6</a>
</li>
<li> <i>This is Heroin</i> (2002) <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1860744249" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-86074-424-9</a>
</li>
<li> <i>The Heroin User's Handbook</i> by <a href="/wiki/Francis_Moraes" title="Francis Moraes">Francis Moraes</a> (paperback 2004) <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1559502169" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-55950-216-9</a>
</li>
<li> <i>The Little Book of Heroin</i> by Francis Moraes (paperback 2000) <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0914171984" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-914171-98-4</a>
</li>
<li> <i>Heroin: A True Story of Addiction, Hope and Triumph</i> by Julie O'Toole (paperback 2005) <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1905379013" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-905379-01-3</a>
</li>
<li> <i>The Heroin Diaries: A Year in the Life of a Shattered Rockstar</i> by Nikki Sixx (2007) <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780743486286" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-0-7434-8628-6</a>
</li>
<li> <i>Heroin: The Myths and the Facts</i> by Richard Ashley (1972), St. Martin's Press, Library of Congress No. 72-89417
</li>
<li>"The Death Proclamation of Generation X: A Self-Fulfilling Prophesy of Goth, Grunge and Heroin" by Maxim W. Furek, M. (2008), i-Universe. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780595463190" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-0-595-46319-0</a>
</li>
<li> <i>Seeds of Terror: How Heroin is Bankrolling the Taliban and Al Qaeda</i>, by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gretchen_Peters_(journalist)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gretchen Peters (journalist) (page does not exist)">Gretchen Peters</a>, publ. Thomas Dunne Books (2009)
</li>
<li> Forbes, Andrew&#160;; Henley, David (2011). Traders of the Golden Triangle. Chiang Mai: Cognoscenti Books. ASIN: B006GMID5K
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.unodc.org/unodc/en/drugs/afghan-opium-survey.html">UNODC – United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime – Afghan Opium Survey 2009</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nida.nih.gov/Infofacts/heroin.html">NIDA InfoFacts on Heroin</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.whitehousedrugpolicy.gov/drugfact/heroin/">ONDCP Drug Facts</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://historyofalcoholanddrugs.typepad.com/alcohol_and_drugs_history/heroin/index.html">Heroin news page</a> – <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alcohol_and_Drugs_History_Society&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alcohol and Drugs History Society (page does not exist)">Alcohol and Drugs History Society</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.scribd.com/doc/120817550/The-Protocols-Of-The-Learned-Experts-On-Heroin-by-Thomas-Szasz">Protocols of the Learned Experts on Heroin</a> <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Szasz" title="Thomas Szasz">Thomas Szasz</a> M.D.
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://druginfo.nlm.nih.gov/drugportal/dpdirect.jsp?name=Heroin">U.S. National Library of Medicine: Drug Information Portal – Heroin</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.geopium.org/">Geopium: Geopolitics of Illicit Drugs in Asia, especially opium and heroin production and trafficking in and around Afghanistan and Burma (Articles and maps and French and English)</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.NAABT.org/">National Alliance of Advocates for Buprenorphine Treatment – non-profit education website for treatment of Heroin addiction</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://usinfo.state.gov/is/Archive_Index/Pakistans_Cultivation_of_Opium_Drops.html">United States Department of State fact sheet: anti-narcotics efforts in Pakistan</a> – dated 7 June 2002
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/4647018.stm">BBC Article entitled 'When Heroin Was Legal'. References to the United Kingdom and the United States</a>
</li>
</ul>
